fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.bodyText: • A review of Robert Hewison’s book Cultural Capital: The Rise and Fall of Creative Britain in last Saturday’s Review section (page 7) described him as “a critic, curator, academic and Hazlitt scholar”. John Ruskin is his academic speciality, not William Hazlitt. • An article about the appointment of the Rev Libby Lane as the Church of England’s first female bishop said “there is no block on women being cathedral deans [but] only three of the 44 English cathedrals are run by women today”. Only six of the 42 English cathedrals are run by women, that should have said (‘Remarkable for me, historic for the church’: Anglicans welcome their first female bishop, 18 December, page 3). • In a feature about the Canadian singer-songwriter Kiesza (My pop year, 19 December, page 9, G2), we said the video for her song Hideaway, which was posted on YouTube in February this year, had since been viewed “a staggering 12m times”. In fact it has been viewed a breathtaking 169m times; another copy of the video, posted on YouTube in April, has racked up more than 13m views.
